knimeNode.name: Tracing View
knimeNode.shortDescription: Provides visualization of supply chains and allows forward and backward tracing.

fullDescription.intro: This node can visualize a supply chain. The three mandatory input ports expect a station table, an delivery table and a delivery relations table. These tables are provided by the Supply Chain Analyzer. Tracing can be performed by setting the following four properties for stations and deliveries: "Case Weight", "Cross Contamination", "Kill Contamination" and "Observed". You can change the property values by double clicking on a station/delivery or by using "Station/Delivery Selection -> Show Properties" from the context menu. Based on these properties the following values are computed: "Score", "Normalized Score", "Positive Score", "Negative Score", "Forward", "Backward". The results of the tracing or any other data from input tables can be visualized by using highlighting (as explained below).

tab.name: Station Properties
tab.option: Weights for stations. The computed scores are based on these weights.
Set cross contamination for stations. That means all incoming deliveries can contaminate all outgoing deliveries (see "Enforce Temporal Order").
Set kill contamination for stations. That means contaminations from incoming deliveries are killed and do not spread to outgoing deliveries.
For all stations/deliveries that can reached by forward/backward tracing from stations selected here, the "Forward"/"Backward" property is set to true.

tab.name: Delivery Properties
tab.option: Weights for deliveries. The computed scores are based on these weights.

Set cross contamination for deliveries. Similar to "Station Cross Contamination", but unselected (no cross contamination) incoming deliveries and outgoing deliveries, that are only connected to unselected incoming deliveries, are excluded from the cross contamination.
Set kill contamination for deliveries. That means contaminations from these deliveries are killed and do not spread to outgoing deliveries.
For all stations/deliveries that can reached by forward/backward tracing from deliveries selected here, the "Forward"/"Backward" is set to true.

When checked a svg graphic instead of a png is put in the ouput port.

This button can be used to switch between the usual graph view and a geographical view. Is only enabled if latitude and longitude for stations are provided in columns "GeocodingLatitude" and "GeocodingLongitude".

Here the use can choose between different GIS visualizations. If a shape table is provided to the optional input port, the type "Shapefile" is also available. All types other types than "Shapefile" require an internet connection, since data downloaded from OpenStreetMap, ...

tab.name: Date Slider
tab.option: If checked, all deliveries without a date are not shown.
Only deliveries whose date is before the date specified here are shown.

tab.name: Options Bar
tab.option: Current editing mode. If "Transforming" is selected the user can move the graph by using the mouse. In "Picking" mode the user can select and unselect stations and deliveries.
If checked, a legend with all highlight conditions, which have "Show in Legend" activated, is display in the lower left corner of the canvas.
If checked, deliveries with the same source and target are joined.
If checked, arrows are drawn in the middle of each delivery.
If checked, stations without any connected deliveries are not shown.
Font Size and type (plain or bold) can be specified here. This font is used for station/delivery labels and in the legend.
Min/Max diameter of the stations. Min value is used, when no "Value Condition" or "Logical Value Condition" is defined for stations. Otherwise the station sizes are between min and max.
Min/Max thickness of the deliveries. Min value is used, when no "Value Condition" or "Logical Value Condition" is defined for deliveries. Otherwise the delivery thicknesses are between min and max.
If checked, geographical stations that occlude each other are moved so that the user can see each station.
Small Label, that is displayed in the upper right corner of the graph image.
If checked, deliveries from a meta station to itself are shown.
Alpha value used to draw the geographical borders.
If checked, the delivery date is used for cross contamination. That means a delivery can only contaminate deliveries with a later date.
If checked, all invisible deliveries, that can be reached from the visible deliveries only via the cross contamination specified by the user, are made visible.

tab.option: Resets translation and scale to default.
The image as can be saved as a PNG- or SVG-file.
Several graph layout algorithms (e.g. Fruchterman-Reingold) can be applied here. The algorithms are applied to the selected stations and to all stations if no stations are selected.

tab.name: Highlight Condition List Dialog
tab.option: This dialog lets you manage the Highlight Conditions, either for stations or deliveries. To edit a Condition double click on it.
Adds a new Highlight Condition to the list.
Removes the selected Highlight Condition from the list.
If selected, the color of each condition overwrites all colors of conditions below it. Otherwise the colors are mixed.

tab.name: Highlight Condition Dialog
tab.option: Type of the condition: "Logical Condition", "Value Condition" or "Logical Value Condition". Types are explained in the sections below.
Name of the condition. The name is used in the "Highlight Condition List Dialog" and in the legend.
If selected the condition will be shown in the legend.

Color of the highlighted elements. For a logical conditions all true elements are painted. For a value condition all elements with values > 0 are painted (the higher the value the higher alpha value used for painting).
If selected all true elements and elements with values > 0 are made invisible.
If selected the size/thickness of the station/delivery will be adjusted based on the value of the station/delivery.
Property, that should be used as a label for all true elements and elements with values > 0.

tab.name: Logical Condition
tab.option: A logical condition is an And/Or conjunction of logical expressions like "City == Berlin" or "Inhabitants > 10". It can only be true or false.
When a logical condition consists of multiple expressions, And/Or conjunctions between these expressions must be specified. "And"-conjunctions will be evaluated before "Or"-conjunctions.
Property of the logical expression. Is compared to "Value".
Type of the logical expression.
Value of the logical expression. Is compared to "Property".

tab.name: Value Condition
tab.option: A value condition uses numerical properties, for example "Log value of Inhabitants".
Property of the value condition.
Type of the value condition. If "Log Value" is used, the logarithmic function with base 10 is applied to all property values, before visualizing. For "Value" no function is applied.

tab.name: Logical Value Condition
tab.option: A logical value condition is a value condition that is only applied to elements, for which the logical condition is true.
